descriptions.content:
Unlike the inferential perfect (and to a certain extent the assertive), the egophoric perfect auxiliary is not widely used. The use of this auxiliary is a complex matter, and it is restricted to a small class of volitional verbs. For example, with the non-volitional verbs ན་ “to be sick” or མཐོང་ “to see,” the egophoric perfect aspect may not be used. Even some volitional verbs such as ཟ་ “eat,” ལྟ་ “look” are not compatible with the egophoric perfect. In this case, one must instead use the perfective forms.

  • ང་ན་བྱུང་། “I fell ill, I have fallen ill.” (Not *ང་ན་ཡོད།)
  • ངས་མཐོང་བྱུང་། “I saw, I have seen.” (Not *ངས་མཐོང་ཡོད།)
  • ངས་ཁ་ལག་བཟས་པ་ཡིན། “I ate, I have eaten the food.” (Not *ངས་ཁ་ལག་བཟས་ཡོད།)
  • ང་ཕྱིན་པ་ཡིན། “I have gone (there).” (Not *ང་ཕྱིན་ཡོད། )

However with some volitional verbs[1] such as བཟོ་ “prepare,” འབྲི་ “write,” སྡོད་ “stay,” etc. the egophoric aspect frequently occurs.

  • ངས་ཁ་ལག་བཟོས་ཡོད། “I have prepared the food.” (The food is here, ready.)
  • ངས་ཡི་གེ་བྲིས་ཡོད། “I have written the letter.” (The letter is here.)
  • ང་ནང་ལ་བསྡད་ཡོད། “I have stayed at home.” (I am still there.)   

Note: The negative forms of the egophoric and assertive perfect auxiliaries are more widely used than the affirmative forms. They are often even preferred to the simple perfective, and may occur with non-volitional verbs. Thus, negation in the past tense blurs the distinction between the perfect and perfective aspects.

For example, ང་ཕྱིན་མེད། “I haven’t gone” is more commonly heard than ང་མ་ཕྱིན།, and similarly, ཁོང་ཕེབས་ཡོད་མ་རེད། “He hasn’t gone” rather than ཁོང་མ་ཕེབས་པ་རེད།.

Nevertheless, perfective forms may be used to emphasize the subject’s refusal to perform the action: ང་(ངས་)མ་ཕྱིན། “I didn’t go.” (I didn’t go even though I was supposed to.) In some cases like this one, the ergative case can be used with an intransitive volitional verb, in order to put an emphasis on the subject.

 

 

[1] In most cases, the compatibility of the perfect depends on whether the object of the transitive verb (or the subject of an intransitive verb) exists objectively after the completion of the action and is still present.
